Yagiz Erkan wrote:
> Hi all,
> 
> We've been debating about keeping the programmer tests in the same 
> package as
> the code (they reside in physically separated folder structures) or in a
> separate package structure. I think it is a good practice to keep the 
> tests as
> clients to the code. This implies that the tested "units" are public. 
> However,
> it seems to be a good package design to have a small external interface,
> without revealing the internal activity. Testing the public interface, 
> in this
> case, makes the units too coarse grained and it isn't satisfactory. 
> Isn't that
> a good argument to keep the programmer tests in the same package 
> structure as
> the code?

Yes, but another way to show clients narrower interfaces is to use 
Interface Segregation, rather than the visibility keywords. Your clients 
talk to your classes mostly through interfaces, so you can control the 
amount they see without having to wrestle with method visibility to do 
your testing.
